sen.j: 上杉氏（うえすぎし、うえすぎうじ）は、日本の氏族の一つ。
sen.e: Uesugi clan (Uesugi-shi, Uesugi-uji) is one of the clans in Japan.
The Uesugi Clan (pronounced either Uesugi-shi or Uesugi-uji in Japanese) was a Japanese clan.
sen.cmt: Added "The"Capitalized 'c'"Uesugi-shi, Uesugi-uji"→"pronounced either Uesugi-shi or Uesugi-uji in Japanese""is one of the clans in Japan"→"was a Japanese clan"
sen.e: The Uesugi clan (pronounced either Uesugi-shi or Uesugi-uji in Japanese) was a Japanese clan.

sen.j: 元は公家であるが、鎌倉幕府の将軍に選ばれた親王の従者として関東に下向し、武士化した。
sen.e: Originally a court noble, it was picked by the Shogun of Kamakura Shogunate as a servant to a prince and went to Kanto, then became warriors.
Originally aristocrats, they became warriors after moving to Kanto as vassals of Prince Munetaka when he was chosen to be Shogun,
sen.cmt: "a court noble"→"aristocrats"Sentence mistranslated - the Prince was chosen to be Shogun not the clan to be his vasslas
sen.e: Originally aristocrats, they became warriors after moving to Kanto as vassals of Imperial Prince Munetaka when he was chosen to be Shogun.

sen.j: 京都府綾部市上杉が名字の地。
sen.e: Uesugi, Ayabe City, Kyoto Prefecture is the place from which the surname was taken.
They took their name from Uesugi in Ayabe City, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: "is the place from which the surname was taken"→"They took their name from" and movedAdded "in"
sen.e: They took their name from Uesugi in Ayabe City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代、室町時代から江戸時代にかけて栄えた武家の一族が著名である。
sen.e: The warrior family that prospered from Kamakura and Muromachi Periods to Edo Period is well-known.
They are well-known for being a warrior family that prospered from the Kamakura and Muromachi Periods to the Edo Period.
They are well-known for being a warrior family that prospered from the Kamakura and Muromachi Periods to the Edo Period.

sen.j: 藤原北家勧修寺流の流れを汲み、鎌倉時代の中頃まで京都の中級公家の家柄であった、重房の代に至って丹波国何鹿郡上杉庄（うえすぎのしょう、現在の京都府綾部市上杉町周辺）を領したことにより上杉を名字とした。
sen.e: Belonging to the Kajuji line of Fujiwara North Household, it was a mid-class court noble family, but during the generation of Shigefusa it put in charge of Uesugi no Sho in Ikaruga District of Tanba Province (present-day vicinity of Uesugicho, Ayabe City, Kyoto Prefecture), thereby acquiring the surname of Uesugi.

Belonging to the Kajuji line of the Northern (Hokke) Fujiwara, they were a middle rank aristocratic family until the mid-Kamakura Period, when Shigefusa Kajuji was put in charge of Uesugi no Sho in Ikaruga District of Tanba Province (present-day vicinity of Uesugicho, Ayabe City, Kyoto Prefecture), thereby acquiring the surname of Uesugi.
sen.cmt: "line"→"branch""Fujiwara North Household"→"the Northern (Hokke) Fujiwara""it was a mid-class court noble family"→"they were a middle rank aristocratic family"Added "until the mid-Kamakura Period""but during the generation of Shigefusa it"→"when Shigefusa Kajuji was"
sen.e: Belonging to the Kajuji line of the Northern (Hokke) Fujiwara, they were a middle rank aristocratic family until the mid-Kamakura Period, when Shigefusa Kajuji was put in charge of Uesugi no Sho in Ikaruga District of Tanba Province (present-day vicinity of Uesugicho, Ayabe City, Kyoto Prefecture), thereby acquiring the surname of Uesugi.

sen.j: 足利尊氏は当地で産まれたとの伝承が残る。
sen.e: There is a lore that Takauji ASHIKAGA was born in this region.
There is a tradition that Takauji ASHIKAGA was born in this region.
There is a tradition that Takauji ASHIKAGA was born in this region.

sen.j: 元々は、天皇家に仕える公家であったが、鎌倉時代後期、親王の将軍就任に従って鎌倉へ下向してのちに武士となった。
sen.e: Originally, they were court nobles who served the Imperial Family, but they moved to Kamakura upon the prince's installation as Shogun during late Kamakura Period, after which they became warriors.

Originally, they were court nobles who served the Imperial Family, but they moved to Kamakura upon Prince Munetaka's installation as Shogun during the late Kamakura Period, after which they became warriors.

Originally, they were court nobles who served the Imperial Family, but they moved to Kamakura upon Imperial Prince Munetaka's installation as Shogun during the late Kamakura Period, after which they became warriors.

sen.j: のち足利氏の姻戚として勢力を伸ばした。
sen.e: They later expanded their power as relatives of Ashikaga clan.
They later expanded their power as relatives of Ashikaga clan.
They later expanded their power as relatives of Ashikaga clan.

sen.j: 室町時代は鎌倉府にあって鎌倉公方の執事、次いで関東管領の職を世襲し、相模国、武蔵国、上野国、越後国など一門で4ヶ国の守護職を占める有力守護大名としても栄えた。
sen.e: During Muromachi Period they passed on the stewardship of Kamakura kobo and subsequently Kanto kanrei position through hereditary succession, and they also prospered as a powerful shugo daimyo family that single-handedly occupied Shugoshiki in 4 provinces of Sagami. Musashi, Kozuke and Echigo.

During the Muromachi Period they passed on the stewardship of the Kamakura Kubo and subsequently the Kanto Kanrei position through hereditary succession, and they also prospered as a powerful shugo daimyo family that held the governorship of Sagami, Musashi, Kozuke and Echigo Provinces.
sen.cmt: Added "the""kobo"→"Kubo"Added "the"Capitalized 'k'"single-handedly occupied Shugoshiki in 4 provinces"→"held the governorship"Full stop→commaAdded "Provinces"
sen.e: During the Muromachi Period they passed on the stewardship of the Kamakura Kubo and subsequently the Kanto Kanrei position (a shogunal deputy for the Kanto region) through hereditary succession, and they also prospered as a powerful shugo daimyo family that held the governorship of Sagami, Musashi, Kozuke and Echigo Provinces.
sen.cmt: 関東管領、説明補足 (A shogunal deputy for the Kanto region)

sen.j: しかし、従来より鎌倉府に仕え関東に拠点のあった山内上杉家と、当初は室町幕府に仕えて京都に在住した扇谷上杉家が、関東の覇権をかけて内紛を起こし次第に勢力を衰退させる。
sen.e: However, their power gradually declined due to the internal strife over hegemony in Kanto between Yamanouchi Uesugi family that was already based in Kanto and had been serving Kamakura-fu, and the Ogigayatsu Uesugi family that originally lived in Kyoto and served Muromachi-fu.

However, their power gradually declined due to internal strife over hegemony in Kanto between the Yamanouchi Uesugi family that was already based in Kanto and had been serving Kamakura-fu, and the Ogigayatsu Uesugi family that originally lived in Kyoto and served Muromachi-fu.

However, their power gradually declined due to internal strife over hegemony in Kanto between the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family that was already based in Kanto and had been serving Kamakura-fu, and the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family that originally lived in Kyoto and served Muromachi-fu.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)には関東における覇権を、次第に新興勢力である後北条氏に押され、山内上杉家の当主上杉憲政は、越後守護代として勢力を台頭させていた長尾氏の長尾景虎（後の上杉謙信）に上杉の名跡を譲った。
sen.e: During the Period of Civil War, hegemony over Kanto was gradually taken over by the newly arising force of Go-Hojo clan, and the head of Yamanouchi Uesugi family, Norimasa UESUGI, passed on the name of Uesugi to Kagetora NAGAO (later Kenshin UESUGI) of Nagao clan who was gaining power as shugodai in Echigo.

During the Warring States Period, control of Kanto was gradually taken over by the newly arising force of the Go-Hojo Clan, and the head of the Yamanouchi Uesugi family, Norimasa UESUGI, passed on the Uesugi name to Kagetora NAGAO (later Kenshin UESUGI) of the Nagao Clan, who was gaining power as the Governor of Echigo.
sen.cmt: "Period of Civil War"→"Warring States Period"Added "Provinces""hegemony over"→"control of"Added "the"capitalized 'c'Moved "Uesugi"Added "the"capitalized 'c'Added comma"shugodai in"→"the Governor of"
sen.e: During the Warring States Period, control of Kanto was gradually taken over by the newly arising force of the Gohojo clan, and the head of the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family, Norimasa UESUGI, passed on the Uesugi name to Kagetora NAGAO (later Kenshin UESUGI) of the Nagao clan, who was gaining power as the Governor of Echigo.

sen.j: 景虎は山内上杉家督、関東管領就任により上杉政虎（輝虎）と名乗った。
sen.e: Kagetora took on the name of Masatora (Terutora) UESUGI upon succeeding as the head of Yamanouchi Uesugi family and assuming the position of Kanto Kanrei.
Kagetora took the name of Masatora (Terutora) UESUGI upon succeeding as head of the Yamanouchi Uesugi family and assuming the position of Kanto Kanrei.
Kagetora took the name of Masatora (Terutora) UESUGI upon succeeding as head of the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family and assuming the position of Kanto Kanrei.

sen.j: これにより再び上杉氏は勢いを取り戻し、その養子上杉景勝（長尾氏のうち長尾氏より）は豊臣政権の五大老を務め、会津藩120万石。
sen.e: Through this, Uesugi clan gradually regained power, and his adopted son, Kagekatsu UESUGI (from Nagao clan within Nagao clan), served as a Go-tairo in the Toyotomi government and received Aizu domain with 1.2 million koku.

Through this, the Uesugi Clan gradually regained power and his adopted son, Kagekatsu UESUGI (of the Nagao Clan), served n th Council of Five Elders (Go-Tairo) in the Toyotomi government and received Aizu domain, worth 1.2 million koku.
sen.cmt: Added "the"Capitalized 'c'The section in brackets makes no sense in Japanese or English so reworded it"as a Go-tairo"→"on th Council of Five Elders (Go-Tairo)""with"→", worth"
sen.e: Through this, the Uesugi clan gradually regained power and his adopted son, Kagekatsu UESUGI (of the Nagao clan), served n th Council of Five Elders (Go-Tairo) in the Toyotomi government and received Aizu domain, worth 1.2 million koku.

sen.j: 江戸時代は米沢藩30万石（実高51万石）を領した。
sen.e: During Edo Period he ruled Yonezawa domain with 300,000 koku (510,000 koku in actuality).
During the Edo Period he ruled Yonezawa domain, worth 300,000 koku (in reality 510,000 koku).
During the Edo Period he ruled Yonezawa domain, worth 300,000 koku (in reality 510,000 koku).

sen.j: のち無嗣の危機に瀕したこともあり15万石（実高33万石）に減知されたが、幕末まで大名としての地位を維持した。
sen.e: Later, they faced a crisis of having no heir, and they were demoted to 150,000 koku (330,000 in actuality), but they maintained their position as a daimyo until the end of Edo Shogunate.
Later, they faced a crisis of having no heir, and they were demoted to 150,000 koku (in reality 330,000), but they maintained their position as daimyo until the end of Edo Shogunate.
Later, they faced a crisis of having no heir, and they were demoted to 150,000 koku (in reality 330,000), but they maintained their position as daimyo until the end of Edo Shogunate.

sen.j: 明治時代は華族に列し、伯爵を授けられた。
sen.e: During Meiji Period they were included as a new nobility, and they were given the title of earl.
During the Meiji Period they were included in the new nobility and given the title of earl.
sen.cmt: Added "the""as a"→"in the" Deleted comma and "they were"
sen.e: During the Meiji Period they were included in the new nobility and given the title of earl.

tit.j: 鎌倉時代・南北朝時代・室町時代
tit.e: Kamakura Period and the Period of Southern and Northern Courts.
Kamakura Period and Period of the Southern and Northern Courts.
Kamakura Period and Period of the Southern and Northern Courts.

sen.j: 初代上杉重房のとき、鎌倉幕府の征夷大将軍に迎えられた宗尊親王に従って鎌倉へ下向し、有力御家人の足利氏と姻戚関係を結んだ。
sen.e: During the first-generation period of Shigefusa UESUGI, they descended to Kamakura with Prince Munetaka who was installed as Seii Taishogun of Kamakura Shogunate, and they became relatives of the powerful feudal lord, Ashikaga clan, through arranged marriages.

During the time of the first Uesugi, Shigefusa, they moved to Kamakura with Prince Munetaka, who was installed as Seii Taishogun of the Kamakura Shogunate, and they became relatives of the powerful vassal family, the Ashikaga Clan, through arranged marriages.
sen.cmt: "the first-generation period of"→"the time of the first Uesugi, Shigefusa,""descended"→"moved""feudal lord"→"vassal family"Added "the"Capitalized 'c'
sen.e: During the time of the first Uesugi, Shigefusa, they moved to Kamakura with Imperial Prince Munetaka, who was installed as Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Kamakura Shogunate, and they became relatives of the powerful vassal family, the Ashikaga clan, through arranged marriages.
sen.cmt: 征夷大将軍、説明補足 (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")Clan→clanImperialを追加しました。

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)、重房の孫・上杉憲房は妹の上杉清子が足利尊氏・足利直義兄弟の母であったことから尊氏を助けて功績を立て、上野国の守護に任ぜられて関東地方で南朝方の新田氏と戦った。
sen.e: During the Period of Southern and Northern Courts, Shigefusa's grandson, Norifusa UESUGI, was assigned as Shugo of Kozuke Province for rendering a distinguished service by helping Takauji because his younger sister, Kiyoko UESUGI was the mother of brothers Takauji ASHIKAGA and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA, and he fought against Nitta clan of Southern Court in Kanto Area.

During the Period of the Southern and Northern Courts, Shigefusa's grandson, Norifusa UESUGI, whose younger sister, Kiyoko UESUGI, was Takauji and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA's mother, was assigned as Shugo (governor) of Kozuke Province as a reward for helping Takauji, and he fought against the Southern Court supporters, the Nitta Clan, in the Kanto Area.
sen.cmt: Added "the", (governor)"for rendering a distinguished service by"→"as a reward for""because his younger sister, Kiyoko UESUGI was the mother of brothers Takauji ASHIKAGA and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA"→"whose younger sister, Kiyoko UESUGI, was Takauji and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA's mother," and movedMoved "Southern Court"Added "supporters", comma, "the"Capitalized 'c'Added "the"
sen.e: During the Period of the Southern and Northern Courts, Shigefusa's grandson, Norifusa UESUGI, whose younger sister, Kiyoko UESUGI, was Takauji and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA's mother, was assigned as Shugo (governor) of Kozuke Province as a reward for helping Takauji, and he fought against the Southern Court supporters, the Nitta clan, in the Kanto Area.

sen.j: また、重房の別の孫は題目宗の僧となって日静と名乗り、京本圀寺や越後国三条本成寺（新潟県三条市）を有した。
sen.e: Furthermore, another grandson of Shigefusa became a monk named Nichijo of Daimoku-shu School, who owned Hongoku-ji Temple in Kyoto as well as Honjo-ji Temple in Sanjo, Echigo Province (Sanjo City, Niigata Prefecture).

Furthermore, another grandson of Shigefusa became a monk named Nichijo, who followed the Daimoku doctrine and owned Hongoku-ji Temple in Kyoto, as well as Honjo-ji Temple in Sanjo, Echigo Province (Sanjo City, Niigata Prefecture).
sen.cmt: "of Daimoku-shu School, who"→", who followed the Daimoku doctrine and"Added comma
sen.e: Furthermore, another grandson of Shigefusa became a monk named Nichijo, who followed the Daimoku doctrine and owned Hongoku-ji Temple in Kyoto, as well as Honjo-ji Temple in Sanjo, Echigo Province (Sanjo City, Niigata Prefecture).

sen.j: 師の名僧日印の問答対決を「鎌倉殿中問答」にまとめ、宗門の興隆を導いた。
sen.e: He edited his accomplished master, Nichiin's debate in "Kamakura Denchu Mondo" and was implemental in the prospering of this school.
He edited "Kamakura Denchu Mondo", a collection of his accomplished master, Nichiin's debates and was implemental in the prospering of this school.
He edited 'Kamakura Denchu Mondo,' a collection of his accomplished master, Nichiin's debates and was implemental in the prospering of this school.

sen.j: その後、観応の擾乱では高氏と対立するなど波乱もあったが、憲房の子の上杉憲顕の時代には上野・越後国・伊豆国の守護を兼ねた。
sen.e: Later, during Kanno Disturbance, there were troubles such as confrontations against Ko clan, but during Norifusa's son, Noriaki UESUGI's time he served as Shugo of Kozuke, Echigo Provinces and Izu Province.

Later, during the Kanno Disturbance, there were troubles such as confrontations with the Ko Clan, but during Norifusa's son, Noriaki UESUGI's time, the family became Shugo of Kozuke, Echigo and Izu Provinces.
sen.cmt: Moved "there were troubles such as confrontations against Ko clan""against"→"with"Capitalized 'c'Added "the""he served as"→", the family became"Deleted "Provinces"Made final "Province plural
sen.e: Later, during the Kanno Disturbance, there were troubles such as confrontations with the Ko clan, but during Norifusa's son, Noriaki UESUGI's time, the family became Shugo of Kozuke, Echigo and Izu Provinces.

sen.j: 上杉憲顕が1363年に鎌倉公方足利基氏の執事（管領）に任ぜられて、初代の関東管領になって以来、鎌倉に居住した一族から犬懸（いぬかけ）、山内（やまのうち）、宅間（たくま）、扇谷（おうぎがやつ）の4家が出た（頭に居住地名を冠している）。
sen.e: In 1363, Noriaki UESUGI was assigned as a steward (kanrei) of Kamakura Kubo Motouji ASHIKAGA, and since he became the first generation Kanto kanrei 4 families developed from one single family that lived in Kamakura: Inukake, Yamanouchi, Takuma and Ogigayatsu (the name of the residential are is used at the beginning of the surname).

In 1363, Noriaki UESUGI was assigned as a steward (Kanrei) of Kamakura Kubo Motouji ASHIKAGA, and after he became the first Kanto Kanrei, the family split into four branches: the Inukake, the Yamanouchi, the Takuma and the Ogigayatsu (the name of their place of residence is used at the beginning of the surname).
sen.cmt: Capitalized 'k'"since"→"after"Deleted "generationCapitalized 'k'"4 families developed from one single family that lived in Kamakura"→"the Kamakura family split into four branches"Added "the" before names"the residential are"→"their place of residence"
sen.e: In 1363, Noriaki UESUGI was assigned as a steward (Kanrei) of Kamakura Kubo Motouji ASHIKAGA, and after he became the first Kanto Kanrei, the family split into four branches: the Inukake, the Yamanouchi, the Takuma and the Ogigayatsu (the name of their place of residence is used at the beginning of the surname).

sen.j: 宅間上杉家は早くに衰え、犬懸上杉家は上杉禅秀の乱により主流派から脱落したので、15世紀半ばからは憲顕の子孫山内上杉家と、憲顕の従兄弟の子孫扇谷上杉家の2家が有力となるが、関東管領の職はもっぱら山内上杉家の当主が独占した。
sen.e: Takuma Uesugi family declined early, and Inukake Uesugi family dropped out from the main lineage after the Uprising of Uesugi Zenshu, therefore, from mid-15th century the 2 families of Yamanouchi Uesugi, the descendants of Noriaki, and Ogigayatsu Uesugi, the descendants of Noriaki's cousin, became dominant, but the Kanto kanrei position was dominated by the head of Yamanouchi Uesugi family.

The Takuma Uesugi family declined early, and the Inukake Uesugi family dropped out from the main lineage after the Uprising of Uesugi Zenshu, therefore, from the mid-15th century the 2 families of the Yamanouchi Uesugi, descendants of Noriaki, and the Ogigayatsu Uesugi, descendants of Noriaki's cousin, became dominant, with the Kanto Kanrei position being dominated by the head of the Yamanouchi Uesugi family.
sen.cmt: Added "The" before family namesAlthough it is part of the name of an incident, I wonder if "Uesugi Zenshu" shouldn't be "Zenshu UESUGI" to conform with other namesDeleted "the "before "descendants""but"→"with""was "→"being"
sen.e: The Takum-Uesugi family declined early, and the Inukake-Uesugi family dropped out from the main lineage after the Uprising of Zenshu UESUGI, therefore, from the mid-15th century the 2 families of the Yamanouchi-Uesugi, descendants of Noriaki, and the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi, descendants of Noriaki's cousin, became dominant, with the Kanto Kanrei position being dominated by the head of the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family.

sen.j: この頃の山内上杉家当主であった関東管領上杉憲実は、足利学校の再興者として歴史に名を残している。
sen.e: Kanto kanrei Norizane UESUGI, who was the head of Yamanouchi Uesugi family at this time, left his name in history as the one who restored the Ashikaga School.
Kanto Kanrei Norizane UESUGI, who was the head of Yamanouchi Uesugi family at this time, made his mark on history as the one who restored the Ashikaga School.
sen.cmt: "left his name in"→"made his mark on"
sen.e: Kanto Kanrei Norizane UESUGI, who was the head of Yamanouchi-Uesugi family at this time, made his mark on history as the one who restored the Ashikaga School.

sen.j: その一方、上杉氏と足利公方家の対立が鮮明となり、1454年には鎌倉公方足利成氏が関東管領上杉憲忠（憲実の子）を殺害したことに発する内乱（享徳の乱）が発生し、関東は応仁の乱よりも十数年早く事実上の戦国時代_(日本)に突入することとなった。
sen.e: On the other hand, antagonism between Uesugi clan and Ashikaga kubo family became clear, and in 1454, an internal strife (Kyoto War) began as a result of Kamakura kubo Shigeuji ASHIKAGA killing Kanto kanrei Noritada UESUGI, and Kanto effectively entered the Period of Civil War (in Japan) over 10 years prior to Onin War.

On the other hand, antagonism between the Uesugi clan and the Ashikaga Kubo family broke into the open and, in 1454, civil war (the Kyotoku Incident) began when Kamakura Kubo Shigeuji ASHIKAGA killed Kanto Kanrei Noritada UESUGI, and Kanto effectively entered the Warring States Period over 10 years prior to the Onin War.
sen.cmt: "became clear"→"broke into the open""an internal strife"→"civil war""Kyoto War"→"the Kyotoku Incident""as a result of"→"when"Capitalized 'k'"Period of Civil War"→"Warring States Period"Deleted "(in Japan)"Added "the"
sen.e: On the other hand, antagonism between the Uesugi clan and the Ashikaga Kubo family broke into the open and, in 1454, civil war (the Kyotoku Incident) began when Kamakura Kubo Shigeuji ASHIKAGA killed Kanto Kanrei Noritada UESUGI, and Kanto effectively entered the Warring States Period over 10 years prior to the Onin War.

sen.j: 享徳の乱の際、扇谷・山内両上杉家は連合して古河公方（鎌倉公方の後身）と敵対していたが、古河公方との和睦後は両家で争うようになり、内紛の末に衰退し、新興の後北条氏に圧迫されるようになる。
sen.e: During Kyoto War, Ogigayatsu and Yamanouchi Uesugi families formed an alliance and warred against Koga kubo (the later form of Kamakura kubo), but after making peace with Koga kubo they began to fight among themselves, and their powers declined at the end of the internal strife, and after Kawagoe Night Battle, they were under pressure by newly risen Go-Hojo clan.

During the Kyotoku Incident, the Ogigayatsu and Yamanouchi Uesugi families formed an alliance and fought against the Koga Kubo (the later form of the Kamakura Kubo) but after making peace, they began to fight among themselves, leading to a decline in their power, and they came under pressure from the emerging Go-Hojo Clan.

sen.e: During the Kyotoku Incident, the Ogigayatsu- and Yamanouchi-Uesugi families formed an alliance and fought against the Koga Kubo (the later form of the Kamakura Kubo) but after making peace, they began to fight among themselves, leading to a decline in their power, and they came under pressure from the emerging Gohojo clan.

sen.j: 武蔵国に勢力をもっていた扇谷上杉家は、1545年の河越夜戦で後北条氏に敗れて滅亡し、上野国を本拠としていた山内上杉家の上杉憲政も、河越夜戦以降は後北条氏の攻撃を直に受けるようになって勢力を衰退させていった。
sen.e: Ogigayatsu Uesugi family, which had power in Musashi Province, lost against Go-Hojo clan at Kawagoe Bight Battle in 1545 and was destroyed, and Norimasa UESUGI of Yamanouchi Uesugi family, who was based in Kozuke Province, began to receive direct attacks from Go-Hojo clan after Kawagoe Night Battle, and their power also began to deteriorate.

The Ogigayatsu Uesugi family, which held power in Musashi Province, was defeated and destroyed by the Go-Hojo Clan at the Kawagoe Night Battle in 1545, and Norimasa UESUGI of the Yamanouchi Uesugi family, who was based in Kozuke Province, began to receive direct attacks from the Go-Hojo Clan, causing their power to also deteriorate.

sen.e: The Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family, which held power in Musashi Province, was defeated and destroyed by the Gohojo clan at the Kawagoe Night Battle in 1545, and Norimasa UESUGI of the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family, who was based in Kozuke Province, began to receive direct attacks from the Gohojo Clan, causing their power to also deteriorate.

sen.j: 憲政はついに関東を放棄し、もとは家臣筋であり外戚でもあった越後長尾氏を頼った。
sen.e: Norimasa finally gave up Kanto, and he relied on Echigo Nagao clan, which originally was of a vassal lineage and also a kin through marriage.
Norimasa finally gave up Kanto, and he came to rely on the Echigo Nagao Clan, which originally was of vassal lineage and also related through marriage.

sen.j: 1561年、憲政は山内上杉家の名跡と関東管領の職を、越後長尾氏の長尾景虎（後の上杉謙信）に譲り、自身は春日山に移った。
sen.e: In 1561, Norimasa passed on the name of Yamanouchi Uesugi and the position as Kanto kanrei to Kagetora NAGAO (later Kenshin UESUGI) of Echigo Nagai clan, and Norimasa moved to Kasuga-yama Mountain.

In 1561, Norimasa passed on the name of Yamanouchi Uesugi and the position of Kanto Kanrei to Kagetora NAGAO (later Kenshin UESUGI) of the Echigo Nagai Clan, and Norimasa moved to Kasuga-yama Mountain.

In 1561, Norimasa passed on the name of Yamanouchi-Uesugi and the position of Kanto Kanrei to Kagetora NAGAO (later Kenshin UESUGI) of the Echigo Nagai clan, and Norimasa moved to Kasuga-yama Mountain.

sen.j: 深谷上杉家の上杉憲盛は武蔵国にとどまって北条氏との戦闘を継続した。
sen.e: Norimori UESUGI of Fukaya Uesugi family remained in Musashi Province and continued to fight against Hojo clan.

sen.j: 以後、長尾氏が上杉氏の嫡流を称する。
sen.e: From then on, Nagao clan claimed themselves as the heir lineage of the Uesugi clan.
From then on, the Nagao Clan proclaimed themselves heirs to the Uesugi Clan.

sen.e: From then on, the Nagao clan proclaimed themselves heirs to the Uesugi clan.

sen.j: 上杉謙信は、越後を拠点として領国を関東と北陸地方に拡大したが、その死後、二人の養子上杉景勝と上杉景虎の間で家督争い（御館の乱）が起こり、この混乱によって関東地方の領国を喪失した。
sen.e: Kenshin UESUGI based himself in Echigo and expanded his territory in Kanto and in the Hokuriku Region, but after his death, a fight to become the head of the family (Otate War) developed between the two adopted sons, Kagekatsu UESUGI and Kagetora UESUGI, and because of this turmoil they lost their territories in the Kanto Region.

Kenshin UESUGI based himself in Echigo and expanded his territory into Kanto and the Hokuriku Region, but after his death, a fight to become the head of the family (Otate War) developed between his two adopted sons, Kagekatsu UESUGI and Kagetora UESUGI, and because of this turmoil they lost their territories in the Kanto Region.

Kenshin UESUGI based himself in Echigo and expanded his territory into Kanto and the Hokuriku Region, but after his death, a fight to become the head of the family (Otate War) developed between his two adopted sons, Kagekatsu UESUGI and Kagetora UESUGI, and because of this turmoil they lost their territories in the Kanto Region.

sen.j: この争いは、長尾一族の出身（越後長尾氏）で謙信の姉の子にあたる景勝が勝利し、上杉氏の名跡を継承するが、謙信・景勝以降の上杉氏（長尾上杉氏）では、謙信を初代、景勝を二代と称している。
sen.e: The son of Kenshin's older sister who was from Nagao family (Echigo Nagao clan), Kagekatsu, won this war, and he inherited the name of Uesugi clan, but the Uesugi clan (Nagao Uesugi clan) members after Kenshin and Kagekatsu call Kenshin as the first generation and Kagekatsu as the second generation.

Kagekatsu, the son of Kenshin's older sister, who was from the Nagao family (the Echigo Nagao Clan), won this war and inherited the name of the Uesugi Clan, but later members of the clan (the Nagao Uesugi Clan) call Kenshin the first generation and Kagekatsu the second generation.

sen.e: Kagekatsu, the son of Kenshin's older sister, who was from the Nagao family (the Echigo Nagao clan), won this war and inherited the name of the Uesugi clan, but later members of the clan (the Nagao Uesugi clan) call Kenshin the first generation and Kagekatsu the second generation.

tit.j: 安土桃山時代・江戸時代・明治時代
tit.e: Azuchi-Momoyama Period, Edo Period and Meiji Period.

sen.j: 上杉景勝は、織田信長の横死後豊臣秀吉に仕え、五大老の一人となった。
sen.e: Kagekatsu UESUGI served Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI after the death of Nobunaga ODA and he became one of the Go-tairo.
Kagekatsu UESUGI served Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI after the death of Nobunaga ODA, becoming one of the Go-tairo.
Kagekatsu UESUGI served Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI after the death of Nobunaga ODA, becoming one of the Go-tairo.

sen.j: この間、1587年には反抗した新発田重家を攻略して越後を再統一し、1589年には秀吉の命により佐渡国を平定。
sen.e: During this time, in 1587, they captured opposing Shigeie SHIBATA and reunified Echigo, and in 1589 they restored order in Sado Province on Hideyoshi's order.
During this time, in 1587 he captured the rebel Shigeie SHIBATA and reunified Echigo and in 1589, restored order in Sado Province on Hideyoshi's orders.

sen.j: 越後、佐渡、出羽国庄内地方の91万石を領有し、領内に多くの金山を抱えてその実収入は120万石と言われた。
sen.e: They owned 910,000 koku in Echigo and Sado Provinces as well as Shonai region in Dewa Province, and with many gold mines within their territory the actual income was said to have been 1.2 million koku.

He possessed Echigo and Sado Provinces as well as Shonai region in Dewa Province, totaling 910,000 koku, and with many gold mines within their territory, his actual income was said to have been 1.2 million koku.

He possessed Echigo and Sado Provinces as well as Shonai region in Dewa Province, totaling 910,000 koku, and with many gold mines within their territory, his actual income was said to have been 1.2 million koku.

sen.j: 1598年、景勝は隣国の会津藩に移封され、陸奥国の会津・白河藩・田村郡・安達郡・福島藩・伊達郡・庄内（田川郡と飽海郡）・置賜郡、東蒲原郡、佐渡などに総計120万石を領有するが、1600年の関ヶ原の戦いに際して徳川家康に敵対し、米沢藩30万石（実高51万石余）に減封された。
sen.e: In 1598, Kagekatsu was transferred to the neighboring Aizu domain, and his territory of Mutsu Province's Aizu, Shirakawa Domain, Tamura District, Adachi District, Fukushima Domain, Date District, Shonai (Tagawa District and Akumi District), Okitama District, Higashikanbara District and Sado, totaled to 1.2 million koku, but he fought against Ieyasu TOKUGAWA in Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, and he was demoted to 300,000 koku (510,000 koku in actuality) in Yonezawa domain.

In 1598, Kagekatsu was transferred to the neighboring Aizu domain, and his territories of Mutsu Province's Aizu, Shirakawa Domain, Tamura District, Adachi District, Fukushima Domain, Date District, Shonai (Tagawa District and Akumi District), Okitama District, Higashikanbara District and Sado, totaled 1.2 million koku but in the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, he fought against Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and was demoted to 300,000 koku (in reality 510,000 koku) in Yonezawa domain.

sen.j: 1664年、景勝の孫上杉綱勝が急死して断絶の危機を迎えたが、綱勝の舅保科正之（徳川家光の実弟）の尽力により、妹婿吉良義央（上野介、扇谷上杉家の女系子孫）の子上杉綱憲が綱勝の養子に入りした結果、半知15万石（実高30万石余）で家名存続することを許された。
sen.e: In 1664, Kagekatsu's grandson, Tsunakatsu UESUGI, died suddenly and there was a crisis of ending the family, but because of the effort by Tsunakatsu's father-in-law, Masayuki HOSOKAWA (younger biological brother of Iemitsu TOKUGAWA), Tsunanori UESUGI, the son of his daughter's husband, Yoshihira KIRA (Kozu no suke, descendant of the female side of Ogigayatsu Uesugi family) became an adopted son of Tsunakatsu, and as a result the family was permitted to continue its family name with a half stipend of 150,000 koku (30,000 koku in actuality).

In 1664, Kagekatsu's grandson, Tsunakatsu UESUGI, died suddenly and there was a danger of the family dying out, but due to efforts by Tsunakatsu's father-in-law, Masayuki HOSOKAWA, who was a younger brother of Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, Tsunanori UESUGI, the son of his daughter's husband, Yoshihira KIRA (Kozu no suke, descendant of the female side of Ogigayatsu Uesugi family) became an adopted son of Tsunakatsu, and as a result the family was permitted to continue its family name with a half stipend of 150,000 koku (30,000 koku in actuality).

sen.j: 上杉斉憲の代に18万石に加増される。
sen.e: By Narinori UESUGI's generation they were promoted to 180,000 koku.
In Narinori UESUGI's time they were promoted to 180,000 koku.
In Narinori UESUGI's time they were promoted to 180,000 koku.

sen.j: 上杉氏は相次ぐ減封により規模を縮小させたが、越後の春日山城から持ち込んだ上杉謙信の遺骸を米沢城の本丸内に安置し、謙信崇拝に基づいた誇り高い士風を守った。
sen.e: Uesugi's continuous demotions shrank its size, but they enshrined within the main wing of Yonezawa Castle the remains of Kenshin UESUGI brought in from Mt. Kasugayama Castle in Enchigo, and they maintained the proud samurai tradition based on Kenshin Worship.

The continuous demotions reduced the size of the Uesugi, but they enshrined Kenshin UESUGI's remains, brought in from Mt. Kasugayama Castle in Echigo, within the keep of Yonezawa Castle the remains of Kenshin UESUGI, and they maintained a proud samurai tradition based on Kenshin Worship.

sen.e: The continuous demotions reduced the size of the Uesugi, but they enshrined Kenshin UESUGI's remains, brought in from Mt. Kasugayama Castle in Echigo, within the keep of Yonezawa Castle the remains of Kenshin UESUGI, and they maintained a proud samurai tradition based on Kenshin Worship.

sen.j: また、減封のため財政難に悩まされたが、江戸時代後期には上杉鷹山（治憲）が藩の殖産興業を行って財政を立て直した。
sen.e: Furthermore, financial troubles caused by demotions troubled them, but during latter Edo Period Yozan UESUGI (Harunori) rebuilt their economy through encouraging new industries in the domain.

Furthermore, financial troubles caused by the demotions troubled them, but during the latter Edo Period, Yozan (Harunori) UESUGI rebuilt their economy through encouraging new industries in the domain.

sen.j: 明治維新後、米沢藩上杉家は華族に列し、伯爵を授けられた。
sen.e: After Meiji Restoration, Yonezawa Domain Uesugi Family was included as a new nobility and was given a rank of earl.
After the Meiji Restoration, the Yonezawa Domain Uesugi Family was included in the new nobility and given the rank of earl.

sen.j: また、分家米沢藩支藩上杉家は、子爵を受けている。

sen.j: 宇宙工学で宇宙航空研究開発機構宇宙科学研究本部教授の上杉邦憲は米沢藩上杉家の16代目当主にあたる（謙信から数えて17代目）。
sen.e: In Aerospace engineering, Kuninori UESUGI, who is a professor at the Institute of Space and Astronautical Science at Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, is the 16th head of Uesugi family of Yonezawa Domain (17th, counting from Kenshin).

sen.j: 長尾上杉氏以外の系統も、江戸時代まで血統が続いた。
sen.e: The lineages other than Nagao Uesugi clan also continued into Edo Period.
Lineages other than the Nagao Uesugi Clan also continued into the Edo Period.

sen.j: 深谷家上杉憲俊は平福藩藩士になり、宅間上杉家や扇谷家上杉憲勝の子孫は旗本になったと云われる。
sen.e: Noritoshi UESUGI of Fukaya family became a hanshi of Hirafuku Domain, and it is said that the descendants of Takuma Uesugi family and Norikatsu UESUGI of Ogigayatsu Uesugi family became hatamoto.

sen.j: 上杉満定の男系子孫である加賀爪氏は江戸幕府譜代大名となった。
sen.e: Descendants of the male side of Mitsusada UESUGI became a fudai daimyo of Edo Shogunate,
Descendants of the male side of Mitsusada UESUGI became fudai daimyo during the Edo Shogunate,

sen.j: 上条政繁（上杉入庵）の次男・上杉長員の子孫は、旗本（高家）上杉氏として存続し、領地は下総国印旛郡・千葉郡などである。
sen.e: Descendants of Nagakazu UESUGI, the second son of Masashige JOJO (Nyuan UESUGI), survived as hatamoto (koke) Uesugi clan, and their territory included Inba District and Chiba District of Shimousa Province.

Descendants of Nagakazu UESUGI, the second son of Masashige JOJO (Nyuan UESUGI), survived as the hatamoto (koke) Uesugi Clan, and their territory included Inba District and Chiba District in Shimousa Province.

sen.j: 長男・景広の子孫は能登畠山家として上杉家に仕え、三男・義真の子孫も旗本（のち高家）畠山氏、上杉綱憲の挙兵を止めたのがその末裔である畠山義寧（千坂や色部だというのは俗説）である。
sen.e: Descendants of the eldest son, Kagehiro, served the Uesugi family as Noto Hatakeyama family, and the descendants of the third son, Yoshizane, also became hatamoto (later koke) Hatakeyama clan, and the one who stopped Tsunanori UESUGI's dispatching of troops was Yoshiyasu HATAKEYAMA (opinions that suggest Chizaka and Irobe are myths), the descendant of Yoshizane.

sen.j: 上杉氏には数多くの分家があり、上杉頼重、上杉憲房の子息の代で分かれた以下の系統が著名である。
sen.e: There are many branch families of Uesugi clan, and the following lineages that branched out during the generations of the sons of Yorishige UESUGI and Norifusa UESUGI are well-known.

sen.j: 室町時代は隆盛したが、戦国時代以降の混乱によりいずれも没落しており、その末裔は上記のように旗本や諸藩士になる者が多く、江戸時代に大名として存続したのは長尾氏から上杉謙信を養子に迎えた山内上杉宗家と加賀爪氏のみとなった。
sen.e: They prospered during Muromachi Period, but they all declined because of the turmoil after the Period of Civil War, and as noted above, many of their descendants became hatamoto or hanshi of various domains, and the only ones that remained in existence as daimyo during Edo Period were Kagatsume clan and the main family of Yamanouchi Uesugi clan who adopted Kenshin UESUGI from Nagao clan.

They prospered during the Muromachi Period, but they all declined in the turmoil after the Warring States Period and, as noted above, many of their descendants became hatamoto or hanshi of various domains, the only ones remaining as daimyo during the Edo Period being the Kagatsume clan and the main Yamanouchi Uesugi Clan, who adopted Kenshin UESUGI from the Nagao Clan.

sen.e: After Fusatada's death, there was a mutiny such as Fusayoshi UESUGI's suicide schemed by Tamekage NAGAO who supported Sadazane UESUGI, and after Tamekage's death Sadazane UESUGI attempted to regain power with the support of Date clan, but he was defeated in Tenbun War and died without an heir, thereby eliminating the family line in 1550.

sen.cmt: Added comma"do not berate people"→"will not find fault with others"
sen.e: When there is no confusion in your heart, you will not find fault with others.
